5.0	RMP Program Level Determination

The USEPA regulations assigned three different levels of complexity to the RMP program, depending on certain criteria at the particular plant in question.  The GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility qualifies as Program 1 plant based on several factors.  Specifically, the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility is eligible for Program 1 because: (1) there are no public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from a worst-case release; (2) the process has had no release of a regulated substance (29% ammonium hydroxide) in the past five years where exposure to the substance has resulted in one or more offsite deaths, injuries, or response/restoration activities for exposure to an environmental receptor; and (3) the facility has coordinated their emergency response activities with the local responders.

4.0.3	Alternative Release Scenario Analysis.  The alternative release scenario [40 CFR Part 68.28] is considered the most likely release to occur from a covered process that is expected to produce the greatest distance to a toxic endpoint.  The Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance provided by the USEPA recommends that the alternative release scenario be based on the following:

1.	The scenario most likely to occur.

2.	The meteorological conditions at the time of the release are characterized by a wind speed of 3 meters per second (m/s), an ambient temperature of 77°F (25°C), and an atmospheric stability class D.

3.	Active as well as passive mitigation systems may be included in the analysis (if applicable).

The alternative release scenario most likely to cause off-site consequences is a release of the entire contents of a single 56,000-liter ammonium hydroxide storage tank, which is located within the HPM Dispense building.  A catastrophic release from the 56,000-liter storage tank would be contained within the secondary containment system for the ammonium hydroxide storage tanks.  The vapor emissions from the spilled ammonium hydroxide would be ventilated and exhausted through an acid scrubber with a minimum of 90% [normally operating @ 98% ]removal efficiency (ER)) ER before entering the atmosphere.  

The active mitigation measures of venting ammonium hydroxide emissions through the acid scrubber were considered as part of this alternative release scenario.

1.0	Purpose

The Purpose of this document is to describe the applicability of ammonia solutions at concentrations greater than 20% at the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility in Malta, New York.

2.0	RMP Applicability for Ammonium Hydroxide

Ammonium Hydroxide used at the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility in Malta, New York is listed as a regulated substance in 40 CFR §68.130.  The threshold quantity for ammonium solutions at concentrations greater than 20% is 20,000 pounds.  The two 56,000-liter storage tanks, located in the HPM Dispense building, contain approximately 64,405 pounds of ammonia in total when full (in the form of 29% ammonia hydroxide solution).  These ammonia hydroxide tanks will feed product into the Delivery System Process located in the Fab 8 building, which is described below.

2.0	Ammonium Hydroxide Storage and Delivery System Process Description within the Fab 8 Building

4.0	Hazard Assessment

4.0.1	Introduction. A Hazard Assessment was conducted for the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility in accordance with 40 CFR 68 Subpart B.  The Hazard Assessment consists of the following tasks:

1.	worst-case release scenario analysis
2.	alternative release scenario analysis
3.	defining off-site impacts - population and environmental receptors
4.     five-year accident history

The GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility currently uses 29% ammonium hydroxide solution, which is on the list of regulated toxic substances (40 CFR Part 68.130). The toxic endpoint for concentrations of ammonium hydroxide greater than 20% is 0.14 mg/L.
